title: Skeleton of a mermaid? No, two real photos combined into one fake
subtitle: An
author: africacheck.org
vclaim:
showing what appears to be a freshly excavated mermaid skeleton has been making the rounds on social media. It

the top half of a human skeleton joined at the pelvis to a headless skeleton of a fish.

The photo has been shared on

with the comment, “Mermaid!?”, and

with the caption: “Skeleton of a Mermaid”.

It’s been online for at least seven years. In June 2012 a

published the photo with a report that it was an “ancient skeleton of a mermaid discovered by a professor”.

A reverse image search reveals that the image has been manipulated, with two different photos – one of a fish skeleton, another of a human skeleton – put together to make the fake mermaid skeleton.

was published on an archaeology blog on 21 October 2011. There it is

BI South, Haymarket, and described as a person “carefully buried just to the south in the foundation trench of an early eighteenth-century house on Haymarket” in Ireland.

first appeared online as an entry in

. It’s credited to a designer with the screen handle

We examined the image’s metadata using an

and found it was created in Photoshop in June 2012 – around the time it appeared on the

The image has also been debunked by fact-checkers at

And there’s no harm in repeating the fact that
